prompt: Facts: Marriage between Arnesh Kumar (Appellant) and Sweta Kiran (Respondent No. 2) solemnized on July 1, 2007.; Sweta Kiran alleged demands for dowry (Rs. 8 Lakhs, a Maruti car, an air-conditioner, a television set etc.) by Arnesh Kumar and his family.; Sweta Kiran alleged she was driven out of the matrimonial home due to non-fulfillment of these dowry demands.; Sweta Kiran lodged FIR No. 197/2012, dated 'Insufficient data' (prior to High Court petition), at P.S. Mahila Thana, Patna.; FIR registered under Section 498A of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961.; Arnesh Kumar apprehended arrest based on the FIR.; Appellant Arnesh Kumar sought Anticipatory Bail before the Sessions Judge, Patna, which was rejected.; Appellant filed an application under Section 482 Cr.P.C. before the High Court of Patna seeking quashing of the FIR, which was also dismissed on October 24, 2013.; Appellant appealed the High Court's decision before the Supreme Court of India, primarily seeking protection against arrest.; Supreme Court noted statistical data indicating a high number of arrests under Section 498A IPC, often including relatives, with a low conviction rate.; Supreme Court observed that arrest brings humiliation, curtails freedom, and casts scars forever, and should not be a routine procedure.; The core issue addressed by the Supreme Court was the procedure for arrest by police, especially concerning offences punishable with imprisonment for a term which may be less than seven years or which may extend to seven years; whether with or without fine, in light of Section 41 and 41A of the Cr.P.C. | IPC: Section 498A IPC (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty), Section 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 (Penalty for demanding dowry), Section 41 Cr.P.C. (When police may arrest without warrant - Discussed extensively), Section 41A Cr.P.C. (Notice of appearance before police officer - Discussed extensively)
